spans.content: AHI 1C Final Exam:
Pointillism (c.1885–1910, Neo-Impressionism)
A painting technique involving the systematic application of small, distinct dots of pure color. Rather
than mixing pigments on a palette, artists relied on optical blending to occur in the viewer’s eye. This
method reflects Neo-Impressionism’s engagement with scientific rationalism, chromatic theory, and a
rejection of the spontaneity of Impressionism. The movement sought a more ordered, “objective” visual
language rooted in perception and structure.
? Example: Georges Seurat’s A Sunday on La Grande Jatte (1884–86) demonstrates compositional
precision and a calculated approach to modern life.
Collage (early 20th c., Cubism & Modern Art)
An artistic technique involving the assemblage of diverse materials—newspapers, wallpaper,
photographs, etc.—onto a single surface. Pioneered by Analytic and Synthetic Cubism, collage
challenged the illusionism of traditional painting by emphasizing materiality, surface, and the
fragmentation of vision. It embodies Cubism’s philosophical shift toward multiple perspectives and a
deconstructed picture plane.
? Example: Picasso’s Guitar (1912) uses cut cardboard and string to blur boundaries between two- and
three-dimensional space.
Automatic Drawing (c.1920s, Surrealism)
A technique of drawing executed without conscious intent, meant to bypass rational control and access
the unconscious mind. This practice reflects Surrealism’s central interest in Freudian psychoanalysis,
especially the expression of repressed desires and dream logic. Automatic drawing is a form of
automatism, allowing the artist to become a conduit for psychic forces rather than a conscious designer.
? Example: André Masson’s Automatic Drawing (1924) features fluid, unpredictable forms that
emerge from the subconscious.
Impasto (17th–20th c., Renaissance to Modernism)
A technique of applying paint thickly so that its texture and the gesture of the artist’s brush or knife
remain visible. While present in Baroque and Romantic art, in modern contexts impasto became a key
means of material expressiveness and emotional intensity, especially in Post-Impressionism and
Expressionism. It emphasizes the physicality of painting and the artist’s subjective presence.
? Example: Van Gogh’s Starry Night (1889) uses dynamic, swirling impasto to suggest movement and
psychological tension.
Abject Art (1990s–present, Contemporary)
An art practice that engages with the abject—materials or themes that are taboo, repulsive, or
transgressive, such as bodily fluids, wounds, or decay. Influenced by Julia Kristeva’s theory of the
abject, this form of art challenges normative boundaries between the self and the “other.” It aligns with
postmodern critiques of identity, the body, and cultural repression.
? Examples: Damien Hirst’s vitrines of animal corpses or Kiki Smith’s bodily sculptures foreground
the visceral and marginal.
Photojournalism (mid-19th–20th c., Modern Media)
A mode of photography intended to document real-life events with immediacy and truth-value, forming
a key part of visual journalism. Photojournalism reflects the modernist belief in objectivity and the
indexical power of photography as a record of time and place. It also became a powerful tool for social
reform through its ability to evoke empathy.
? Examples: Mathew Brady’s Civil War documentation or Dorothea Lange’s Migrant Mother (1936)
during the Great Depression.
Readymade (c.1910s, Dada)
A found object that is designated as art by the artist, without aesthetic transformation. Coined by Marcel
Duchamp, the readymade was a radical challenge to aestheticism, craftsmanship, and the aura of the
artwork. It embodied Dada’s anti-art ethos, attacking bourgeois taste and the institutional definitions of
Example: Duchamp’s Fountain (1917)—a porcelain urinal—is a seminal work of conceptual art.
Grattage (c.1926, Surrealism)
A Surrealist painting technique involving the scraping of wet paint across textured surfaces (e.g., fabric,
leaves) to generate unexpected patterns and forms. Developed by Max Ernst, grattage exemplifies the
Surrealist goal of automatism through material processes, merging chance and subconscious association
into visual form.
? Example: Max Ernst’s Forest and Dove (1927) evokes eerie, dreamlike landscapes through accidental
textures.
Camera Obscura (antiquity–19th c.)
An optical device consisting of a darkened box or room with a small aperture through which light enters,
projecting an inverted image onto a surface. It served as an aide to draftsmanship and precursor to
photography, helping artists achieve linear perspective and naturalistic rendering during the Renaissance
and beyond. Its use reflects the merging of art and optics before the invention of the camera.
? Example: Vermeer is believed to have used a camera obscura to aid in his precisely lit interiors.
En Plein Air (mid-19th c., Barbizon & Impressionism)
A French term meaning “in the open air,” this practice involves painting outdoors to capture natural
light, atmosphere, and ephemeral effects. Central to Impressionist aesthetics, it reflects their emphasis
on direct observation, changing light conditions, and a rejection of studio idealization.
? Example: Monet and Renoir painted river scenes and gardens en plein air, often at different times of
day to study light.
Japonisme (1870s–1890s, Western Impressionism & Post-Impressionism)
The Western fascination with Japanese art and design, especially ukiyo-e prints, which influenced
European artists in their use of asymmetrical composition, flat color planes, and decorative patterning.
Japonisme reflects modernism’s embrace of non-Western aesthetics as alternatives to academic realism,
while also raising questions about cultural appropriation.
? Example: Van Gogh incorporated Japanese stylistic motifs in works like The Flowering Plum
Orchard (1887).
Social Realism (1930s, American Scene / Regionalism)
An art movement committed to portraying everyday life and the struggles of the working class in a
realistic, often somber style. Social Realism was politically motivated, responding to the Great
Depression and advocating for social change through figurative representation and accessible imagery.
? Examples: Dorothea Lange’s documentary photographs or Grant Wood’s American Gothic (1930)
offered critiques or affirmations of American life.
Spirit Photography (c.1860s–, Spiritualism)
A photographic practice that claimed to capture ghosts or spirits of the deceased, emerging alongside the
19th-century Spiritualist movement. Though often fraudulent, these images reflect cultural anxieties
around death, mourning, and the afterlife, and reveal photography’s early association with truth and
mysticism.
? Example: William H. Mumler’s portrait of Mary Todd Lincoln with Abraham Lincoln’s “spirit”
(1869) is infamous.
Art for Art’s Sake (mid-19th c., Aestheticism)
A slogan and philosophy asserting that art need not serve moral, political, or practical purposes—its
value lies in formal beauty and self-expression. Central to the Aesthetic Movement, it opposed Victorian
utilitarianism and embraced artifice, decorativeness, and the autonomy of art.
? Examples: James McNeill Whistler’s tonal harmonies and Oscar Wilde’s literary defense of aesthetic
autonomy.
Primitivism (late 19th–early 20th c., Modernism)
A modernist appropriation of the visual languages of non-Western and prehistoric cultures, often
idealized as more “pure” or spiritually authentic. Primitivism challenged Western academic conventions,
but also reflects colonialist attitudes, projecting Western fantasies onto “the Other.” It played a central
role in modernist formal experimentation.
? Examples: Gauguin’s Tahitian paintings or Picasso’s Les Demoiselles d’Avignon (1907), which
incorporates African mask motifs.
Style & Movement Analysis
Romanticism (c.1800–1850)
Key Concepts: Romanticism centers on the sublime, martyrdom, dramatic gestures, and emotional
excess.
Features: The movement favors loose brushwork, dynamic compositions, stark chiaroscuro, and
patriotic or heroic themes.
Historical Context: Emerging in the aftermath of the Enlightenment, Romanticism responded to the
French Revolution and conflicts such as the Peninsular War in Spain.
Example: Francisco Goya’s The Third of May, 1808 presents an unheroic depiction of political violence
and martyrdom, emphasizing raw emotion over idealized narrative.
Realism (c.1840–1880)
Key Concepts: Realism emphasizes class consciousness, the dignity of labor, and a rejection of
idealization in favor of truthful representation.
Features: Earthy color palettes, flattened compositions, and depictions of rural or working-class life
typify this style.
Historical Context: Influenced by industrialization and the rise of the working class, Realism reflects
the social tensions surrounding the 1848 revolutions in Europe.
Example: Gustave Courbet’s The Stone Breakers captures the physical burden and invisibility of labor
through repetition and unvarnished realism.
Photography (19th–20th century)
Key Concepts: Photography introduced new possibilities for documentation, artistic experimentation,
and visual truth through technological innovation.
Features: Images are typically highly detailed, monochromatic, and emphasize formal composition and
realism.
Historical Context: Born out of the industrial and scientific revolution, photography intersected with
spiritualism and mass media.
Example: Alfred Stieglitz’s The Steerage (1907) exemplifies modern composition and comments on
class and immigration.
Impressionism (c.1870–1885)
Key Concepts: Impressionism values fleeting light effects, perceptual immediacy, and the experience of
modern urban leisure.
Features: It is characterized by en plein air painting, visible brushwork, cropped viewpoints, and a
bright, saturated palette.
Historical Context: The movement coincided with Haussmann’s transformation of Paris and the
emergence of a bourgeois middle class.
Example: Claude Monet’s Impression: Sunrise captures the transient effects of light and atmosphere
over precise detail.
Post-Impressionism (c.1885–1905)
Key Concepts: This movement pushes beyond Impressionism, exploring symbolism, psychological
depth, color theory, and formal structure.
Features: Artists developed personal visual languages using bold color, expressive form, and
experimental composition.
Historical Context: Post-Impressionists sought spiritual and emotional resonance amidst
disillusionment with modernity.

? Examples: Gauguin’s Tahitian paintings or Picasso’s Les Demoiselles d’Avignon (1907), which

Style & Movement Analysis
Romanticism (c.1800–1850)
Key Concepts: Romanticism centers on the sublime, martyrdom, dramatic gestures, and emotional
excess.
Features: The movement favors loose brushwork, dynamic compositions, stark chiaroscuro, and
patriotic or heroic themes.
Historical Context: Emerging in the aftermath of the Enlightenment, Romanticism responded to the
French Revolution and conflicts such as the Peninsular War in Spain.
Example: Francisco Goya’s The Third of May, 1808 presents an unheroic depiction of political violence
and martyrdom, emphasizing raw emotion over idealized narrative.
Realism (c.1840–1880)
Key Concepts: Realism emphasizes class consciousness, the dignity of labor, and a rejection of
idealization in favor of truthful representation.
Features: Earthy color palettes, flattened compositions, and depictions of rural or working-class life
typify this style.
Historical Context: Influenced by industrialization and the rise of the working class, Realism reflects
the social tensions surrounding the 1848 revolutions in Europe.
Example: Gustave Courbet’s The Stone Breakers captures the physical burden and invisibility of labor
through repetition and unvarnished realism.
Photography (19th–20th century)
Key Concepts: Photography introduced new possibilities for documentation, artistic experimentation,
and visual truth through technological innovation.
Features: Images are typically highly detailed, monochromatic, and emphasize formal composition and
realism.
Historical Context: Born out of the industrial and scientific revolution, photography intersected with
spiritualism and mass media.
Example: Alfred Stieglitz’s The Steerage (1907) exemplifies modern composition and comments on
class and immigration.
Impressionism (c.1870–1885)
Key Concepts: Impressionism values fleeting light effects, perceptual immediacy, and the experience of
modern urban leisure.
Features: It is characterized by en plein air painting, visible brushwork, cropped viewpoints, and a
bright, saturated palette.
Historical Context: The movement coincided with Haussmann’s transformation of Paris and the
emergence of a bourgeois middle class.
Example: Claude Monet’s Impression: Sunrise captures the transient effects of light and atmosphere
over precise detail.
Post-Impressionism (c.1885–1905)
Key Concepts: This movement pushes beyond Impressionism, exploring symbolism, psychological
depth, color theory, and formal structure.
Features: Artists developed personal visual languages using bold color, expressive form, and
experimental composition.
Historical Context: Post-Impressionists sought spiritual and emotional resonance amidst
disillusionment with modernity.
Example: Vincent van Gogh’s Café Terrace at Night expresses inner longing and divine connection
through vivid, structured color.
Example: Jackson Pollock’s Full Fathom Five makes visible the unconscious through motion and
material engagement.
Aestheticism (c.1860s–1890s)
Key Concepts: Aestheticism advocates for “art for art’s sake,” prioritizing beauty, formal harmony, and
sensual pleasure over moral or functional concerns.
Features: It often includes tonal harmony, delicate composition, Japanese influences, and decorative
techniques such as gold leaf.
Historical Context: A reaction against industrial ugliness, Aestheticism flourished in Victorian England.
Example: Whistler’s Nocturne in Black and Gold evokes a poetic, atmospheric abstraction through
subtle tones and elegant form.
Pop Art (1950s–1960s)
Key Concepts: Pop Art explores consumerism, mass media, and celebrity through irony and
reproduction.
Features: Artists used bright colors, flat compositions, and commercial imagery to mimic advertising
and comics.
Historical Context: Reflects the prosperity and consumer culture of postwar America.
Example: Warhol’s Marilyn Diptych comments on mass production and the erasure of individual
identity.
Key Concepts: Cubism analyzes form by rejecting illusionism and embracing multiple perspectives,
leading to abstraction and fragmentation.
Features: Common elements include geometric forms, flattened space, reduced color palettes, and the
incorporation of textual or paper elements.
Historical Context: Influenced by photography and African sculpture, Cubism developed in the years
leading up to World War I.
Example: Picasso’s Les Demoiselles d’Avignon displays raw figuration, primitivism, and fractured
visual logic.
Minimalism (1960s)
Key Concepts: Minimalism reduces form to its essentials, focusing on objecthood, repetition, and
spatial interaction.
Features: Works often employ industrial materials, serial forms, and a lack of personal expression.
Historical Context: Reacting against the emotion of Abstract Expressionism, Minimalism redefined the
gallery and viewer experience.
Example: Robert Morris’s Untitled emphasizes physical space and the viewer’s embodied encounter.
Futurism (c.1909–1918)
Key Concepts: Futurism celebrates speed, technology, violence, and modernity, often embracing
destruction as a form of renewal.
Features: Works are marked by diagonal lines, rhythmic motion, repetition, and mechanistic forms.
Historical Context: Born in Italy, Futurism aligned with nationalism and anticipated the technological
brutality of WWI.
Example: Boccioni’s Unique Forms of Continuity in Space fuses the human form with machine-like
energy.
Global Contemporary (1980s–present)
Key Concepts: This diverse era addresses identity, hybridity, postcolonial critique, and global networks.
Features: Practices include video, performance, mixed media, and conceptual strategies rooted in
cultural symbolism.
Historical Context: Shaped by globalization, diaspora, and decolonial discourse, this art engages with
pressing political and social themes.
Examples: Coco Fusco and Guillermo Gómez-Peña’s Couple in a Cage critiques colonial spectacle,
while Kerry James Marshall’s School of Beauty, School of Culture reclaims Black aesthetic identity.
Visual Analysis Framework
I. Formal/Visual Elements
Key Concepts: Dada is anti-art, embracing absurdity, chance, and irrationality to critique the logic that
led to war and bourgeois culture.
Features: Dadaists employed readymades, photomontage, and unexpected juxtapositions to challenge
aesthetic norms.
Historical Context: Developed in Zurich during WWI, Dada reflects disillusionment with
Enlightenment ideals and traditional authority.
Example: Duchamp’s Fountain (1917) subverts institutional definitions of art through conceptual
provocation.
Surrealism (1924–1940s)
Key Concepts: Surrealism investigates dreams, the unconscious, and repressed desire, drawing from
Freudian psychoanalysis.
Features: Artists used detailed illusionism, biomorphic abstraction, and surreal juxtapositions to explore
irrationality.
Historical Context: The movement arose in interwar Europe, reflecting disillusionment and a search for
deeper psychological truth.
Example: Dalí’s The Grand Masturbator visualizes erotic symbolism and unconscious fantasy.
Ashcan School (c.1900–1915)
Key Concepts: This American movement captures the gritty realism of urban, working-class life,
bridging realism and modernism.
Features: Loose brushwork, muted palettes, and crowded compositions typify its aesthetic.
Historical Context: The Ashcan School developed amidst industrialization, immigration, and the
growth of urban poverty in New York City.
Example: John Sloan’s McSorley’s Bar (1912) depicts a lively male social space within a blue-collar
saloon environment.
Composition: Centralized / Diagonal / Balanced / Fragmented / Flat / Deep space
Color & Light: Bright / Muted / Natural / Artificial / Chiaroscuro / Symbolic
Line & Shape: Sharp / Curved / Broken / Geometric / Organic
Brushwork & Texture: Smooth / Visible / Impasto / Pointillism / Photographic clarity
Perspective & Space: Linear / Atmospheric / Collapsed / Overlapping planes
Mood: Calm / Chaotic / Emotional / Melancholic / Energetic
Medium & Technique: Oil / Acrylic / Photography / Collage / Readymade / Mixed Media
II. Contextual Elements
Time & Place: Historical era / Political or social climate
Artist’s Background: Nationality / Movement affiliation / Biography
Message or Theme: War, labor, modernity, gender, identity, colonialism, class, trauma, spirituality
Audience: Elite / General public / Political / Religious / Museum / Performance context
Harlem Renaissance (1920s–1930s)
Key Concepts: A cultural movement promoting Black pride, identity, and social critique, often
informed by jazz and Pan-Africanism.
Features: Works frequently include flat, graphic forms, vibrant color, silhouetted figures, and narrative
murals.
Historical Context: Rooted in the Great Migration and Harlem’s cultural boom, this period marked a
flourishing of African American art.
Example: Aaron Douglas’s Aspects of Negro Life: Song of the Towers dramatizes the struggle and
resilience of Black Americans.
Abstract Expressionism (1940s–1950s)
Key Concepts: Focused on existentialism, gesture, and selfhood, Abstract Expressionism marks the rise
of postwar American art.
Features: Large-scale canvases, all-over composition, aggressive brushwork, and abstraction dominate.
Historical Context: Emerged in Cold War-era New York, responding to WWII trauma and asserting
American artistic leadership.
Example: Vincent van Gogh’s Café Terrace at Night expresses inner longing and divine connection
through vivid, structured color.
Example: Jackson Pollock’s Full Fathom Five makes visible the unconscious through motion and
material engagement.
Aestheticism (c.1860s–1890s)
Key Concepts: Aestheticism advocates for “art for art’s sake,” prioritizing beauty, formal harmony, and
sensual pleasure over moral or functional concerns.
Features: It often includes tonal harmony, delicate composition, Japanese influences, and decorative
techniques such as gold leaf.
Historical Context: A reaction against industrial ugliness, Aestheticism flourished in Victorian England.
Example: Whistler’s Nocturne in Black and Gold evokes a poetic, atmospheric abstraction through

Pop Art (1950s–1960s)

reproduction.
Features: Artists used bright colors, flat compositions, and commercial imagery to mimic advertising
and comics.
Historical Context: Reflects the prosperity and consumer culture of postwar America.
Example: Warhol’s Marilyn Diptych comments on mass production and the erasure of individual
identity.
Key Concepts: Cubism analyzes form by rejecting illusionism and embracing multiple perspectives,
leading to abstraction and fragmentation.

Historical Context: Influenced by photography and African sculpture, Cubism developed in the years

Example: Picasso’s Les Demoiselles d’Avignon displays raw figuration, primitivism, and fractured
visual logic.
Minimalism (1960s)
Key Concepts: Minimalism reduces form to its essentials, focusing on objecthood, repetition, and

Features: Works often employ industrial materials, serial forms, and a lack of personal expression.
Historical Context: Reacting against the emotion of Abstract Expressionism, Minimalism redefined the
gallery and viewer experience.
Example: Robert Morris’s Untitled emphasizes physical space and the viewer’s embodied encounter.
Futurism (c.1909–1918)
Key Concepts: Futurism celebrates speed, technology, violence, and modernity, often embracing

Features: Works are marked by diagonal lines, rhythmic motion, repetition, and mechanistic forms.
Historical Context: Born in Italy, Futurism aligned with nationalism and anticipated the technological
brutality of WWI.
Example: Boccioni’s Unique Forms of Continuity in Space fuses the human form with machine-like
energy.

Features: Practices include video, performance, mixed media, and conceptual strategies rooted in

Historical Context: Shaped by globalization, diaspora, and decolonial discourse, this art engages with

Composition: Centralized / Diagonal / Balanced / Fragmented / Flat / Deep space
Color & Light: Bright / Muted / Natural / Artificial / Chiaroscuro / Symbolic
Line & Shape: Sharp / Curved / Broken / Geometric / Organic
Brushwork & Texture: Smooth / Visible / Impasto / Pointillism / Photographic clarity
Perspective & Space: Linear / Atmospheric / Collapsed / Overlapping planes
Mood: Calm / Chaotic / Emotional / Melancholic / Energetic
Medium & Technique: Oil / Acrylic / Photography / Collage / Readymade / Mixed Media
II. Contextual Elements
Time & Place: Historical era / Political or social climate
Artist’s Background: Nationality / Movement affiliation / Biography
Message or Theme: War, labor, modernity, gender, identity, colonialism, class, trauma, spirituality
Audience: Elite / General public / Political / Religious / Museum / Performance context
Harlem Renaissance (1920s–1930s)
Key Concepts: A cultural movement promoting Black pride, identity, and social critique, often
informed by jazz and Pan-Africanism.
Features: Works frequently include flat, graphic forms, vibrant color, silhouetted figures, and narrative
murals.
Historical Context: Rooted in the Great Migration and Harlem’s cultural boom, this period marked a
flourishing of African American art.
Example: Aaron Douglas’s Aspects of Negro Life: Song of the Towers dramatizes the struggle and
resilience of Black Americans.
Abstract Expressionism (1940s–1950s)
Key Concepts: Focused on existentialism, gesture, and selfhood, Abstract Expressionism marks the rise
of postwar American art.
Features: Large-scale canvases, all-over composition, aggressive brushwork, and abstraction dominate.
Historical Context: Emerged in Cold War-era New York, responding to WWII trauma and asserting
American artistic leadership.
